title: Bill Armstrong (coach)
text:
Richard "Bill" Armstrong (July 16, 1873 – August 4, 1938) was an American <a href="college%20football">college football</a> player and coach. He served as the head football coach at the <a href="College%20of%20William%20%26amp%3B%20Mary">College of William & Mary</a> in 1896, the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a> from 1897 to 1899 and the Hampton Institute—now known as <a href="Hampton%20University">Hampton University</a>—in 1912, compiling a career college football coaching record of 24–8. At the Naval Academy, Armstrong also coached <a href="Rowing%20%28sport%29">rowing</a> from 1897 to 1899. 
Armstrong was born on July 16, 1873, at his grandfather's home in <a href="Saybrook%2C%20Connecticut">Saybrook, Connecticut</a>. His parents, William Nevins Armstrong and Frances Morgan Armstrong, were residents of <a href="Hampton%2C%20Virginia">Hampton, Virginia</a>. His uncle, <a href="Samuel%20C.%20Armstrong">Samuel C. Armstrong</a>, was an American Civil War general who founded Hampton University. Armstrong attended the Banner School in Hampton and <a href="Phillips%20Academy">Phillips Academy</a> in <a href="Andover%2C%20Massachusetts">Andover, Massachusetts</a> before moving on to <a href="Yale%20University">Yale University</a> from which he graduated from <a href="Sheffield%20Scientific%20School">Sheffield Scientific School</a> in 1895.
Armstrong married Rosa Fairfax Lee in Hampton, on April 21, 1906. He later worked in the oyster growing, farming and real estate professions.
In May 1938, Armstrong was treated for a serious illness at <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Hospital">Johns Hopkins Hospital</a> in <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>. He returned to his home in Hampton in June, where he died on August 4, 1938 after suffering a paralytic stroke.
